title: Early-Onset Alzheimer's Disease Case Study: John, a 45-year-old Former Executive
clinical_history: John, a 45-year-old former executive, was diagnosed with Early-Onset Alzheimer's disease (EOAD) 2 years ago. He initially presented with difficulties in word retrieval and spatial navigation. Over time, his symptoms have progressed to include significant memory loss, confusion, and difficulty with daily tasks. He requires assistance with most activities of daily living and has noticeable changes in mood and behavior. Recently, John has been experiencing increased stiffness and rigidity, particularly in the morning, which affects his mobility and balance.
aggrevating_factors: Prolonged sitting or standing, transitions from sitting to standing, and walking long distances
picture: A 24-hour picture showing increased stiffness in the morning and evening, with some relief after gentle exercise
easing_factors: Gentle stretching, short walks, and warm baths
past_history: History of hypertension, controlled with medication. No previous history of musculoskeletal issues.
medical_history: Diagnosed with Early-Onset Alzheimer's disease 2 years ago. Currently taking donepezil and memantine.
medications: Donepezil 10mg daily, memantine 10mg twice daily, and lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension
personal_history: Married with two teenage children. He was a former executive and had to retire early due to his condition. He enjoys reading and spending time with his family.
imaging: MRI scans show significant atrophy in the temporal lobes, consistent with EOAD. X-rays of the spine and hips show mild degenerative changes.
